name: 1913 Copper Miners strike, Michigan
description: A commemorative site and blog established to coordinate activities relating to the centennial of the 1913-14 Michigan Copper Miners’ Strike.

name: AFSCME Roll of Honor
description: A marker placed to honor men and women who put their lives on the line, emphasizing the need for safety measures and OSHA coverage for public employees.
address: 444 E Main St, New Britain, CT 06051, USA

name: American Factory Worker Sculptures
description: Six statues originally exhibited at the 1933 Chicago Century of Progress Exposition, discovered in storage rooms of the Museum of Science & Industry.
address: 5700 S DuSable Lake Shore Dr, Chicago, IL 60637, USA

name: A. Phillip Randolph Pullman Porter Museum
description: A museum dedicated to the history of A. Phillip Randolph and the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters.
address: 10406 S Maryland Ave, Chicago, IL 60628, USA

name: Alabama Labor History Association
description: An organization currently in formation dedicated to preserving and promoting the labor history of Alabama.

name: American Federation of Labor Founding Marker
description: A state historical marker commemorating the founding of the American Federation of Labor in Pittsburgh.

name: AFL-CIO Headquarters
description: The national headquarters of the AFL-CIO, which serves as a central hub for labor advocacy and also houses various memorials.

name: Allegheny Arsenal Explosion Monument
description: A monument dedicated to the victims of the catastrophic 1862 explosion at the Allegheny Arsenal during the Civil War.

name: American Federation of Labor Headquarters
description: Site of the historic headquarters of the AFL, marked with a plaque to denote its significance in organized labor history.
address: 901 Massachusetts Ave NW, Washington, DC 20001, USA

name: American Federation of Teachers First Office
description: The location of the very first office used by the American Federation of Teachers during its founding years.

name: American Merchant Marine Veterans Memorial
description: A large sculpture and monument honoring the service and sacrifice of American Merchant Marine veterans.

name: Anderson, Colonel James, Monument
description: A monument dedicated to Colonel James Anderson, known for his support of early libraries for working men.

name: American Labor Museum (Botto House)
description: The Pietro and Maria Botto House served as a meeting place during the 1913 Paterson Silk Strike and is now a museum of labor history.

name: American Merchant Seamen Memorial
description: A memorial dedicated to the contributions and memory of merchant seamen on the riverfront.

name: Anthracite Boys Bust
description: A statue commemorating the 'breaker boys' and children who worked in the anthracite coal mines of Pennsylvania.

name: Delaware County Historical
description:
Dairy Farmers' Strikes (1930s & 1941)
Liberty sits in a historic agricultural hub. Local farmers participated in the Milk Strikes of the 1930s, particularly the 1939 and 1941 actions led by the Dairy Farmers Union. Farmers in Sullivan and Delaware counties dumped milk on local roads to protest low prices paid by large distributors, leading to tense standoffs with state police.
address: Hwy, Village of Mayville, Town of Chautauqua, Chautauqua County, New York, 14757, United States

name: Delaware County Historical Association: Dairy Farmers Strikes
description: The Delaware County Historical Association is the primary repository for physical artifacts and documentation of the regional strikes. Their archives hold original photographs and records of the 1939 and 1941 milk dumping and strike barricades that took place on the nearby Delhi-Franklin highway and Meredith town line.

name: The Worker
description: Modeled after Hugh Commiskey, who, with 30 other men, walked from Charlestown to Lowell in the mid 1850’s to begin the work of building and repairing the city’s canals.
address: Market St & Shattuck St, Lowell, MA 01852, USA

name: “Detroit Industry” Frescoes
description: In 1932, Mexican muralist Diego Rivera was commissioned to paint a tribute to Detroit industry and labor. Major sections of the mural are based on the Ford Motor Company’s Rouge industrial complex.

name: “Generations” Sculpture
description: The sculpture represents three generations of sheet metal workers. The senior generation hands the tools of the trade onto the apprentice, as the journeyman looks on. One figure is missing part of the thumb, reflecting the hazards of work.
address: 601 N Fairfax St, Alexandria, VA 22314, USA

name: “Sun” Boys’ Memorial
description: On July 4, 1924, five newspaper boys from the “Baltimore Sun” died when the steamer they were on, the Three Rivers, caught fire. Because they were band members, the memorial reads, “They have all moved a little closer to the Master of all music.”

name: “The History of Labor in America” Murals
description: The murals feature the evolution of labor in America. Each mural represents a specific period and they are respectively titled: Colonization, Settlement, Industry, and Technology.
address: Labor Hall of Honor, 200 Constitution Ave. NW, Washington, DC 20210, USA

name: “The Meaning of Social Security” Mural
description: Ben Shahn’s murals show the hardships of life before the establishment of Social Security, and its benefits–work, the family, and prosperity. Workers in various occupations are shown re-building America through public works projects.
address: 330 Independence Ave SW, Washington, DC 20004, USA

name: “The Prospector” Statue & Alaska Pioneers Home
description: The discovery and mining of gold in Alaska and the pioneering of new territory could offer substantial wealth and fame for prospectors. The Alaska Pioneers Home, started in 1913, was constructed for elderly gold prospectors. Their mission is Providing elder Alaskans a home and community, celebrating life through its final breath.

name: “The Social History of the State of Missouri” Mural
description: Benton portrays carpenters, blacksmiths, farmers, miners, meat processors, and industrial workers. The mural’s condemnation of Missouri’s slave past as well as its celebration of the common worker and farmer caused a political uproar.
address: W Main St, Jefferson City, MO, USA

name: 1913 Copper Miners strike, Michigan
description: This blog has been established to coordinate and promote commemorative activities relating to the centennial of the 1913-14 Michigan Copper Miners’ Strike. More information will be added as it becomes available.

name: A. Phillip Randolph Pullman Porter Museum
description: A non-profit museum honoring the first black labor union, celebrating history and culture through various events and exhibits.
address: 10406 S Maryland Ave, Chicago, IL 60628, USA

name: AFL-CIO Headquarters
description: President Dwight Eisenhower and AFL-CIO President George Meany laid the cornerstone of the building in 1955. The two murals on the ground floor titled, ” Labor is Life” (south) and “Labor Omnia Vincit,” (north) were designed by Lumen Martin Winter..

name: AFSCME Roll of Honor
description: Marker was placed for the men and women who put their lives on the line. It is a recognition of the need for more safety measures and a call to extend OSHA coverage to public employees.
address: 444 E Main St, New Britain, CT 06051, USA

name: Alabama labor history association (in formation)
description:
In formation; see Valley Labor Report radio show
Adam Keller
​

name: Allegheny Arsenal Explosion Monument
description: Memorializes the 43 girls buried here who were killed in the arsenal explosion nearby on Sept. 17, 1862. A total of 75 workers died in the explosion, making it the worst industrial accident associated with the Civil War.

name: American Factory Worker Sculptures
description: Statues were discovered in the Chicago Museum of Science & Industry storage rooms. The 1933 Chicago Century of Progress Exposition exhibited six statues.
address: 5700 S DuSable Lake Shore Dr, Chicago, IL 60637, USA

name: American Federation of Labor Founding State Historical Marker
description: On Nov. 14, 1881, trade unions formed the Federation of Organized Trades and Labor Organizations, later becoming the AFL. Under the leadership of Samuel Gompers and Peter McGuire, the AFL became the most influential labor organization in the nation.

name: American Federation of Labor Headquarters
description: After completion in 1916, the building served as AFL headquarters until 1956. In 1957, the United Association of Journeyman and Apprentices of the Plumbing and Pipefitters Industry moved into the building.
address: Marriott Marquis Washington, 901 Massachusetts Ave NW, Washington, DC 20001, USA

name: American Federation of Teachers First Office
description: This is the first office of the American Federation of Teachers (AFT).
address: 3 S Wabash Ave, Chicago, IL 60603, USA

name: American Labor Museum (AKA the Pietro and Maria Botto House)
description: During the 1913 Paterson Silk Strike, Italian immigrants Pietro and Maria Botto opened their home to the movement, inviting union leaders to speak from their front balcony. From here, thousands of striking silk workers rallied for decent working conditions, an end to child labor, and the eight-hour day. (National Historic Landmark)

name: American Labor Studies Center
description: American Labor Studies Center is a not-for-profit organization whose mission is to collect, analyze, evaluate, create and disseminate labor history and labor studies curricula and related materials, aligned to the various state and national standards, to kindergarten through 12th grade teachers nationwide.
address: 8201 Admiral's Walk Dr, Cohoes, NY 12047, USA

name: American Merchant Marine Veterans Memorial
description: A tribute to the Merchant Marines wartime contributions.
address: Gibson Park, 880 S Harbor Blvd, San Pedro, CA 90731, USA

name: American Merchant Seamen Memorial
description: The American Merchant Marine has served as “the nation’s fourth arm of defense” during many U.S. wars. More than 1,200 Seafarers International Union (SIU) members were killed in WWII, and are included in the ranks of the Merchant Marine.
address: 1315 Chestnut St, St. Louis, MO 63103, USA

name: Amtrak Workers Memorial
description: Memorial honors those Amtrak employees who “lost their lives in performance of their duties.”
address: 50 Massachusetts Ave NE, Washington, DC 20002, USA

name: Anderson, Colonel James, Monument
description: Andrew Carnegie dedicated this monument to the businessman/philanthropist Colonel Anderson who let working boys (like Andrew Carnegie) borrow books from his personal library.
address: Allegheny Square E, Pittsburgh, PA 15212, USA

name: Anthracite Boys Bust
description: Honors “the boys of the anthracite” and is an inspiration to youths brought before Mayor Charles N. Loveland for juvenile offenses.
address: 40 E Market St, Wilkes-Barre, PA 18701, USA

name: Arsenal Monument
description: An accidental explosion at the Washington Arsenal on June 17, 1864, killed at least 21 women who worked filling cartridges for the Union Army during the Civil War.
address: 1801 E St SE, Washington, DC 20003, USA

name: Atlantic City Labor Museum
description: The museum is in the lobby of the city’s original convention center and just across the world-famous Boardwalk from the Atlantic and Cape May County Central Labor Council’s Workers Memorial statue and stone. Its artifacts and exhibits document the importance of union members who have been constructing and serving the resort that became known as the World’s Favorite Playground since the mid-1800s.

name: Atlantic City Workers’ Memorial Monument
description: The Atlantic & Cape May County AFL-CIO Central Labor Council dedicates this Workers' Memorial Monument to honor all Union workers who lost their lives on the job since the establishment of the casino industry in Atlantic City. The new monument and its commemorative inscriptions have been rededicated with a bronze statue at its new location to honor the memory of those who died on October 30, 2003 at the Tropicana garage collapse.

name: Austin at Work
description: The award-winning Austin Public Library (APL) has been the community’s premier source of knowledge, technology, and inspiration for nearly a century. It provides library programs, technology, collections, and space through its state-of-the-art Central Library, Austin History Center, and 20 library branches. It also provides services and resources out in the community through outreach and partnerships.
address: 710 W Cesar Chavez St, Austin, TX 78701, USA

name: Auto-Lite Workers’ Memorial
description: Tribute to the autoworkers who struck in 1934 to build the United Auto Workers (UAW). Electric Auto-Lite workers were brutally attacked by National Guardsmen, and more than 200 were injured in Toledo’s bloodiest labor battle.
address: Champlain St & Elm St, Toledo, OH 43604, USA

name: Avondale Mine Disaster Historical Marker (Avondale)
description: At 10 am, Sept. 6, 1869, one of the worst disasters in the history of US anthracite mining occurred at the Avondale Mine. A fire, originating from a furnace at the bottom of a 237′ deep shaft roared up the shaft killing 110 miners, 80% of whom were Welsh.

name: Avondale Mine Disaster Historical Marker (Scranton)
description: Sept. 6, 1869 one of the worst disasters in US anthracite mining history struck. At Avondale Mine, a furnace fire at the bottom of a 237′ deep shaft roared up the shaft killing 110 miners. 61 victims were buried at Washburn Cemetery on Sept. 9, 1869.

name: Baltimore 1877 Railroad Strike Historical marker
description: Our latest guest blog post comes from Bill Barry, long-time Director of Labor Studies at the Community College of Baltimore County introducing us to the Great Railroad Strike of 1877 and a new historic marker at Camden Station to commemorate the event. We’re also excited to feature a video on the 1877 strike produced for Explore Baltimore Heritage by UMBC student William Carroll for the course Practices in Public History course with Dr. Denise Meringolo.
address: 100 N Charles St Suite P-101, Baltimore, MD 21201, USA

name: Barthell, John, Monument
description: John Barthell, a Finnish native and member of the Western Federation of Miners, was one of 3 people (and the only union member) killed during a union attack on strikebreakers at the Smuggler Mine in 1901.
address: Lone Tree Cemetery, 1000 E Columbia Ave, Telluride, CO 81435, USA

name: Baton Rouge Victory Memorial
description: This memorial is dedicated to the seven merchant seamen who crewed the SS Baton Rouge Victory and lost their lives when the ship was sunk by Viet Cong action en route to Saigon on August 23, 1966.

name: Batsto Village
description: Notable for its preservation of late 19th century worker housing, Batsto was a bog iron and glass making industrial center from 1766-1876. The Batsto Furnace, rebuilt in 1786 and 1829, produced munitions for the Revolutionary War and the War of 1812.

name: Battle of Blair Mountain Historic Site
description: The site where 10,000 striking union miners fought for recognition of their union, UMWA, against coal operators from Aug. 31 to Sept. 4, 1921. At the governor’s request, federal troops were sent in. Miners were forced to withdraw after 16 deaths.

name: Battle of Matewan Historic Site
description: The town is the site of a shootout between striking union miners (led by Police Chief Sid Hatfield) and coal company agents (Baldwin-Felts) on 5/19/1920.
address: 401 Mate St, Blackberry City, WV 25678, USA

name: Battle of the Overpass Historical Marker
description: Remembers the place where Walter Reuther and other union leaders were beaten by Ford “Servicemen” on the overpass bridge in 1937. Photos of the incident destroyed the Ford Co.’s credibility, forcing it to recognize the union in 1941.

name: Bay View Martyrs Historical Marker
description: The Wisconsin Labor History Society placed this marker in honor of those killed by the state militia on May 5, 1886 during a city-wide strike for the 8 hour day. Five workers, a Bay View resident and one young child were shot to death.

name: BC Labour Heritage Centre
description: The BC Labour Heritage Centre Society preserves, documents and presents the rich history of working people and their unions in British Columbia. The Society engages in partnerships and projects that help define and express the role that work and workers have played in the evolution of social policy and its impact on the present and future shaping of the province.
address: 8988 Fraserton Ct #301, Burnaby, BC V5J 5H8, Canada

name: Belleville, Illinois Labor and Industry Museum
description: The Labor & Industry Museum is the only public institution devoted to the history of the labor and industry of Belleville and southwestern Illinois. Belleville was one of the most significant centers for the growth of Illinois industry, which ranked third in the nation in the late 19th century.
address: 123 N Church St, Belleville, IL 62220, USA

name: Big Bend Tunnel Historical Marker
description: Marks the existing tunnel of the C&O Railroad, and is said to be the scene of John Henry’s battle with a steam drill.
address: John Henry Historical Park, 3262 State Hwy 3 and 12, Talcott, WV 24981, USA

name: Bilyeu, George Franklin, Gravesite
description: Erected in memory of George Franklin Bilyeu who was killed in 1898 in Virden, Ill., during a UMWA organizing drive.
address: 820 S Cherokee St block 1, lot 94, site 2, Taylorville, IL 62568, USA

name: Birmingham Civil Rights Institute
description: A civil rights movement gallery and museum across the street from the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church which was bombed in 1963 killing four girls; this infamous event happened less than 3 weeks after the historic March on Washington for Freedom and Jobs.

name: Black Worker Sculpture
description: Done under the Treasury Relief Art Project. On the campus of the Harlem River Houses are wonderful WPA (Works Progress Administration) cast sculptures, two of which celebrate African American culture. The work was done by a team headed by a Jewish emigre escaping Nazi Germany (Heinz Warneke) and which included a prominent and gifted black sculptor (James Richmond Barthe).
address: 64-02A 192nd St apt 3b, Fresh Meadows, NY 11365, USA

name: Bloody Thursday Sculpture
description:
In 1985, Elias ("Dutch") Schultz finished a wood sculpture commemorating the ILWU's 1934 West Coast waterfront strike. The sculpture titled "Bloody Thursday" is on display at Pier 69.
“Bloody Thursday” refers to July 5, 1934 when, during the West Coast waterfront strike, two men, a striker and a strike sympathizer, were shot by police in San Francisco. The International Longshore Workers Union still commemorates Bloody Thursday by closing down ports on West Coast each year on July 5.

name: Bloomington Workers’ Memorial
description: Pavilion and park honors the over 100 local workers who have died on the job.
address: 1020 S Morris Ave, Bloomington, IL 61701, USA

name: Bodega Bay Fisherman’s Memorial
description: Commemorates the dozens of fishermen who have failed to return home to Bodega Head.
address: 1884 Westshore Rd, Bodega Bay, CA 94923, USA

name: Bodie Union Hall
description: The Miners’ Union Local 61, Western Federation of Miners, was organized December 22, 1877, and was one of the first organized unions in California. The Union Hall was erected in 1878 and used for meetings and social events.

name: Boott Cotton Mills Museum
description: The largest industrial museum in the nation outside the Smithsonian. On the grounds of Lowell National Historic Park, Boott Mill No. 6 ceased production in 1954.

name: Bost Building Historical Marker
description: The Bost Building was the Amalgamated Association of Iron & Steel Workers’ headquarters. This office helped direct the workers through one of the bloodiest battles between workers and owners, the 1892 Homestead Strike.

name: Brew, James, gravesite
description: James Brew was killed on July 12, 1917, during the Bisbee Deportation. The Bisbee Deportation was an illegal act where over 1,000 striking miners and their supporters, many of whom were immigrants, were rounded up by vigilantes and local authorities and deported to New Mexico. During the roundup, Brew fired at a group of men entering his rooming house, killing Deputy Sheriff Orson McRae. Brew was then shot and killed in return fire. A coroner's inquest was inconclusive as to who fired the fatal shots. The incident highlights the tensions surrounding the deportation and the violence that erupted during this dark period in Arizona's labor history.
address: 8 Old Douglas Rd, Bisbee, AZ 85603, USA

name: Bridges, Harry (Bust)
description: Honors ILWU President Emeritus Harry Bridges, emblem of the longshore union’s achievements across the latter half of the 20th century.
address: Harry R. Bridges Memorial Building, 1188 Franklin St # 400, San Francisco, CA 94109, USA

name: Brooks, Royal Cyril, Historical Marker
description: Marker commemorating Local 309 FTA-CIO member Royal Cyril Brooks who was murdered on this site in 1948.
address: Huey P Long Ave, Gretna, LA 70053, USA

name: Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers Monument
description: Honors the history of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.
address: 800 E Michigan Ave, Marshall, MI 49068, USA

name: Butte-Anaconda National Historic Landmark plaque
description: "Gibraltar of Unionism": Butte was a hub of unionization and a breeding ground for the American labor movement.

name: Canonsburg Honor Roll Tablet
description: Honors local UMWA members who are now in the armed forces. Also honors the war support of this local union with the purchase of war bonds and participation in the American War Drive.

name: Carbon County Coal Miners' Memorial
description: Memorial to the American coal miner; dedicated to honor the coal miners who lost their lives in Carbon County mines since the beginning of mining in the 1880s.

name: Centralia Tragedy Historic Walking Tour Map (Google Maps)
description: In 1919, American Legionnaires attacked the I.W.W. hall during the Armistice Day parade. Prepared after a similar 1917 assault, Wobblies stood armed inside and across the street. (Part of the Centralia Tragedy Historic Walking Tour on Google Maps)

name: Cesar Chavez Elementary School Mural
description: In 1995, the school, formerly known as Hawthorne Elementary, had a mural painted by Precita Eyes Muralists. The mural, titled Si Se Puede, pays tribute to Cesar Chavez and his vision as the founder of the United Farm Workers Union. The artwork features grape arbors intertwined among the school windows, symbolizing the agricultural richness of California, while red grapes represent the blood of the workers and their tears. The mural has faced challenges over the years. Water damage in 2013 prompted a white stripe of plaster to be added to the wall for stabilization. Despite the efforts, large sections of the damaged area started falling off, posing safety concerns. The mural was vandalized again in 2019
address: 825 Shotwell St, San Francisco, CA 94110, USA

name: Chavez, Cesar (Bust)
description: A founder of the United Farm Workers of America (UFW), Cesar Chavez organized farmworkers during the 1960s, particularly in California.The union used nonviolent tactics like boycotts and hunger strikes to focus attention on farmworker exploitation .
address: 2801 Hop Ranch Rd, Union City, CA 94587, USA

name: Cherry Mine Disaster (100th anniversary memorial)
address: 100 S Main St, Arlington, IL 61312, USA

name: Cherry Mine Disaster Monuments
description: The Cherry Mine Disaster, one of the deadliest mine disasters in United States history, is commemorated by two monuments in Cherry, Illinois. On November 13, 1909, 259 miners died in the underground Cherry Mine fire. As a result of the disaster, the state established stricter safety regulations and in 1911, the basis for the Illinois Workers Compensation Act was passed. The first monument was erected by the United Mine Workers of America, District No. 12, and dedicated in 1911. The second monument, dedicated in 2009, commemorates the 100th anniversary of the disaster.
address: County Rd 1900 N, Cherry, IL, USA

name: Chinese in Nevada State Historical Marker
description: Honoring the thousands of Chinese workers who “played a major role in the history of Nevada . . . where they built railroads, cut timber and performed countless humble tasks.”

name: Chinese Railroad Worker Statue
description: Tribute to the significance of the Chinese worker in the construction of the transcontinental railroad through the Sierra Mountains of California. Working for Central Pacific, Chinese workers lay the connecting rails from the west on May 10, 1869.

name: Chipper Sculpture
description: Artist was awarded the first prize at the 1943 San Francisco Art Show for this piece which depicts the dignity of the worker.

name: Cigar Makers Union Monument
description: Honors the surrounding graves of Chicago cigar makers.
address: 863 Des Plaines Ave, Forest Park, IL 60130, USA

name: CIO Founding Historical Marker
description: At the President Hotel, UMWA President John L. Lewis punched Carpenters Union President Bill Hutcheson in the face, stormed out, and formed the Congress of Industrial Organizations in 1938.

name: Cleveland Labor History Museum & Resource Center
description: Cleveland’s rich labor history mirrors the rest of the country from development and growth to stagnation and decline. Max S. Hayes, Peter Witt and John P. Green all contributed to the growth of Cleveland’s labor movement.

name: Coal Miner, The
description: The statue commemorates the more than 9,000 Illinois coal miners who have lost their lives in mine accidents over the past 130 years prior to 1964.

name: Coal Miner’s Memorial
description: Honors workers who have perished in mine accidents, including 70 who were killed in an explosion near Fairmont in 1968. Recognizes the importance of underground coal mining in the Sheridan County area from the 1800s until 1950. In 1950 surface mining became the preferred method of mining coal.

name: Coal Miners Memorial
description: In the late eighteen hundreds there were many thriving communities that were totally dependent on area coal mines. Now there is a Memorial to honor all miners. Dedicated on October 14th, 2000, the Coal Miners Memorial is a tribute to all Southern Illinois coal miners of the past century. The inscription at the base of the statue reads, “In memory of coal miners who gave so much that future generations may benefit with a better life. They labored, served their country, sacrificed for their families and some lost their lives. We honor and salute them so that they will never be forgotten.”

name: Coal Miners Monument–2.1
description: Historical Marker dedicated to the memory of all the miners in the Carbon-Hanna area who lost their lives in mining accidents. The major accidents occurred in June 1903 and in 1908. 171 men and 58 men were killed respectively.

name: Coit Tower Murals
description: The murals of Coit Tower depict a common theme, “Aspects of Life in California, 1934,” painted by 25 artists and 19 assistants. The murals reflect social, political and labor-related concerns of the Great Depression,
address: Coit Tower, 1 Telegraph Hill Blvd, San Francisco, CA 94133, USA

name: Columbine Massacre Historical Marker
description: In 1927, workers struck for better conditions under the IWW banner. Six miners were killed and many wounded in the Nov. 21 Columbine Massacre. Out of this struggle Colorado coal miners gained lasting union contracts.
address: 7306 W Bowles Ave, Littleton, CO 80123, USA

name: Columbine Massacre Monument
description: On Nov 21 six miners were killed and 60 were injured when state police fired into a 500-person rally during the strike of 1927. Five of the 6 miners are buried here.
address: 7306 W Bowles Ave, Littleton, CO 80123, USA

name: Congress of Industrial Organizations Founding, State Historical Marker
description: To “organize workers into powerful industrial unions,” UMWA President, John L. Lewis called a meeting in Pittsburgh’s Islam Grotto on Nov. 14, 1938, founding the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

name: Connolly, James, Memorial
description: James Connolly, a trade union and socialist organizer in Ireland, Scotland, and the U.S., lived in Troy from 1903-1905. He was among the founding fathers of the radical Industrial Workers of the World.

name: Corti, Elia, Gravesite
description: Elia Corti, an Italian immigrant and anarchist, was shot and killed during a scuffle between anarchists and socialists at the Barre Socialist Labor Hall.
address: Hope Cemetery, 201 Maple Ave, Barre, VT 05641, USA

name: Darr Mine Disaster State Historical Marker
description: An explosion in the Darr Mine on Dec. 19, 1907, killed 239 coal miners, many of whom were Hungarian. Seventy-one of the dead share a common grave in Olive Branch Cemetery. December, 1907, was the worst month in US coal mining history with over 3000 dead.

name: Dawn Mabalon Portrait
description: Portrait of Dawn Mabalon, historian of the Filipino-American community in California and the farmworker movement.

name: Dellums, Cottrell, Lawrence, Monument
description: Dellums, a porter fired by the Pullman Company in 1927 for his organizing activites, co-founded the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters in 1937, the first labor union led by African Americans. He was a vice president of the AFL-CIO until the mid-1980s.

name: Diamond Mine Disaster Marker
description: Diamond mine disaster of 1883 was due to the mine being on a marshy tract of land with no natural drainage. Mid-day Feb. 16, 1883 the snow began to melt and forced a collapse on the east side of the mine. Men and boys scrambled to escape.

name: Dutchman’s Curve Train Wreck
description: The Great Train Wreck of 1918 occurred on July 9, 1918, in Nashville, Tennessee, United States. Two passenger trains, operated by the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway ("NC&StL"), collided head-on, costing at least 101 lives and injuring an additional 171. It is considered the worst rail accident in U.S. history

name: Ely Township Centennial Memorial
description: Memorial stone to miners killed on November 3, 1926 in Barnes-Hecker mine tragedy.

name: Erie County Labor Monument
description: Funded by local and international trade unions to serve as a visible reminder of the contributions of working men and women and as a focal point for organized labor in the future.

name: Eugene V. Debs Museum
description: The Eugene V. Debs Museum is the former house of Eugene V. Debs and Katherine Metzel Debs. After changing hands for many years, it was purchased in 1962 by a small group of Terre Hautians who had a strong admiration for Debs. It is now owned and operated by the Debs Foundation as a free museum.
address: 451 N 8th St, Terre Haute, IN 47807, USA

name: Everest, Wesley, Gravesite
description: Everest was an IWW member lynched by an angry mob for killing an American Legionnaire during 1919 Centralia Armistice Day Riot. Legionnaires were attempting to throw IWW members out of their union hall. Everest killed one soldier while fleeing the hall.
address: 1822 Van Wormer St, Centralia, WA 98531, USA

name: Fire Fighter Memorial #2.-8.1 & Post Point
description: 2.8.1 lists the men who fought the Blackwater fire on August 21, 1937. They died just to the right of the marker. Post Point commemorates the 37 men who took refuge from the fire. Eight died.

name: Firefighters of Michigan Monument
description: Signs on I-75 mark the way to the inscribed stone, dedicated to the firefighters’ unselfish heroism displayed every day while protecting the lives and homes of Michigan citizens.

name: Fisherman’s Memorial
description: Dedicated to fishermen who have lost their lives at sea.

name: Fisherman’s Memorial State Park
description: The local Fisherman’s Association requested that the name of the park be changed from Fort Greene to Fisherman Memorial State Park in honor of all fishermen in the Narragansett area–the tuna capital of the world.
address: 1011 Point Judith Rd, Narragansett, RI 02882, USA

name: Flag Pole Memorial to Wartime Workers
description: First erected as a wartime unity symbol by Chicago & Alten Railroad shop workers. Re-dedicated on April 28, 1993 as a memorial to wartime workers and veterans.

name: Flint Sitdown Strike Historical Marker
description: The Michigan Labor History Society erected this marker to commemorate the General Motors sitdown strike of 1936-1937 which forced GM to recognize the workers’ union and their needs. It led to GM’s first contract with the United Auto Workers.
address: 1901 Executive Plaza Dr, Flint, MI 48507, USA

name: Ford Hunger March
description: 3,000 unemployed auto workers braved the cold on March 7, 1932 to demand jobs and relief from Henry Ford. The marchers got too close to the gate and were gassed. After re-grouping, they were sprayed with water and shot at. 4 men died immediately.

name: Fourth Avenue Business District
description: Developed as the city’s black business district in the early 1900’s because black businesses were forced out of other places by Jim Crow segregation and white owned stores that didn’t welcome black customers.

name: Furuseth, Andrew, Memorial
description: Union leader, Andrew Furuseth, was one of the founders of the SUP and the president of the International Seamen’s Union of America. He was known as the “Abe Lincoln of the Seas.” He was an immigrant from Romedal, Norway and has a monument there as well.
address: 450 Harrison St, San Francisco, CA 94105, USA

name: Furuseth, Andrew, Memorial Bust
description: Union leader, Andrew Furuseth, was one of the founders of the SUP and the president of the International Seamen’s Union of America. He was known as the “Abe Lincoln of the Seas.” He was an immigrant from Romedal, Norway and has a monument there as well.
address: G St NW & 8th St NW, Washington, DC 20001, USA

name: Garcia & Maggini Warehouse
description: On July 3, 1934, employers tried to break the strike that had closed down Pacific coast shipping since May. Trucks began to move goods from the warehouse but striking waterfront workers resisted during a five-hour battle, a prelude to “Bloody Thursday.”
address: 128 King St, San Francisco, CA 94107, USA
website: https://www.foundsf.org/Garcia_and_Maggini_Warehouse (I am not sure if Garcia & Maggini Warehouse have a website)

name: Garment Worker Statue
description: A garment worker sits at his sewing machine portraying generations of immigrant needle-trades workers.

name: Gompers, Samuel, House
description: Samuel Gompers served as president of the American Federation of Labor (AFL) from 1886 until 1924. He lived in this house from 1902 until 1917.

name: Gompers, Samuel, Memorial (DC)
description: Gompers was a Jewish immigrant cigar maker from England who founded the AFL in 1881 and was re-elected as its president 42 times until his death in 1924.

name: Gompers, Samuel, Memorial (TX)
description: Samuel Gompers was the founding president of the American Federation of Labor and the architect of the International Labor Organization. He died in San Antonio in 1924, while attending an international trade union gathering.

name: Granite Mountain Speculator Mine Memorial
description: Honors the 164 to 190 workers killed on June 8, 1917 at Speculator Mine. These non-unionized workers were “roasted to death” 2400′ underground. Three days later, unionizing efforts were undertaken by 10,000-20,000 Butte miners.

name: Greater New Haven Labor History Association
description: Greater New Haven Labor History Association, was founded to collect and preserve the history of Greater New Haven's working people and their unions, said LHA President Steve Kass.
address: 267 Chapel St, New Haven, CT 06513, USA

name: Haley, Margaret A., Plaque
description: Haley was a pioneer of teacher unionism in Chicago and the nation. In 1900, she became the first business representative of the Chicago Teacher Federation. She was a founder of and the first National Organizer for the American Federation of Teachers.
address: 222 W Merchandise Mart Plaza, Chicago, IL 60654, USA

name: Hanapepe Massacre Marker
description: On September 9, 2006, the Kauai Filipino Centennial Celebration Committee dedicated a concrete marker in the Hanapepe Town Park in memory of 16 Filipino workers killed by police during a territory-wide strike of Filipino plantation workers in 1924. Four police officers were also killed. The incident is known as the Hanapepe Massacre.

name: Harmony Mills
description: Formed in 1836, the Harmony Manufacturing Company essentially created a company town in Cohoes, N.Y. The mill workers were never able to organize, despite a strike in 1880 when 5,000 weavers walked off the job.
address: 100 N Mohawk St, Cohoes, NY 12047, USA

name: Harry Bridge Center for Labor Studies, University of Washington
description: On May 14, 1937, a throng of curious students packed the University of Washington Commons building, eager to hear the electric words of a man they had only heretofore read about in newspapers – provocative labor leader Harry Bridges, president of the West Coast longshore workers’ union.
address: Smith Hall, 408 NE Skagit Lane, Seattle, WA 98195, USA

name: Haslam, Bob, Pony Express Memorial
description: A tribute to “Pony” Bob Haslam (1840-1912) who is “considered the greatest of all Pony Express riders.” Credited with the longest trip ridden by an Express rider (380 miles), he served throughout the entire existence of the Pony Express.

name: Hatfield, Sid, Monument
description: Remembers Sid Hatfield, police chief of Matewan, who was killed by Baldwin-Felts Company agents in Aug. 1921 for championing the rights of coal miners to organize a union (UMWA).

name: Haymarket Martyrs’ Monument
description: The monument marks the graves of 7 of the 8 Chicago labor leaders convicted of criminal activity in the largest U.S. demonstration for the 8-hour day (the Haymarket Riot) on May 4, 1886. 4 were executed and 4 were later released by controversial pardon.
address: 863 Des Plaines Ave, Forest Park, IL 60130, USA

name: Henry, John, Monument
description: Commemorates the site where John Henry, in 1870, beat a machine in a steel driving contest and became the most sung about hero in American folklore. Legend says the contest cost him his life and his ghost lives in the Big Bend tunnel.

name: Homestead Historical Marker
description: July 6, 1892 two barges ordered by the Carnegie Steel Co. landed on the south bank of the Monongahela River, sought to occupy Carnegie Steel Works and put down a strike by members of the Amalgamated Association of Iron & Steel Workers.
address: 880 E Waterfront Dr, Munhall, PA 15120, USA

name: Homestead Strikers’ Gravesites
description: Five of the seven workers who died at the Homestead Strike were finally honored with marked graves. The graves are in two adjacent cemeteries.

name: Horton, Roy, Headstone
description: Roy J. Horton was a salesman and supporter of the IWW. He was shot down before the execution of Joe Hill. His assailant was acquitted of manslaughter.
address: 1342 E 500 S, Salt Lake City, UT 84102, USA

name: ICWU/URW Worker Memorial
description: The International Chemical Workers Union and the United Rubber Workers Union unveiled this joint memorial on Workers Memorial Day, 1992. Dedicated to the members who have been killed, or died in workplace tragedies since 1944.
address: 1655 W Market St fl 6, Akron, OH 44313, USA

name: Illinois Labor History Society
description: The Illinois Labor History Society (ILHS) was formed on August 5, 1969 in the office of the late Joseph M. Jacobs, attorney for the Chicago Teachers Union, Meatcutters, and other labor organizations.
address: 430 S Michigan Ave #540, Chicago, IL 60605, USA

name: Illinois Workers’ Memorial
description: Dedicated on Workers Memorial Day, 1992, the statue on the lawn of the state capitol remembers workers who have suffered and died at the workplace. Also honors those who fought to prevent such tragedies in the future.

name: ILWU Monument
description: Commissioned to mark the 50th anniversary of the ILWU, the monument commemorates the police killing of Howard Sperry and Nick Bordoise on “Bloody Thursday,” July 5, 1934. The incident sparked the 1934 general strike and led to the founding of the ILWU.
address: 20 Mission St, San Francisco, CA 94105, USA

name: Iowa Labor History Society
description: The Iowa Labor History Society is a non-profit made up of individuals and affiliate organizations that have joined together to preserve and promote the rich history of Iowa's workers—the lives, labors, and struggles that shaped the history of our state.
address: 2000 Walker Cir a, Iowa City, IA 52245, USA

name: Irish Rail Workers’ Monument
description: Many Irish immigrants worked on the central Illinois railways in the mid-1800s. The more than 50 Irish rail workers layed to rest in the mass graves are presumed victims of the 1850s cholera epidemic.
address: E 535 North Rd, Funks Grove Township, IL 61754, USA

name: Ironworkers Memorial
description: On April 24, 2000, three Ironworkers lost their lives while working on the renovation of the McClugage Bridge.

name: Italian-American Stonecutters Monument
description: Italian immigrants came to Barre in the late 1890s and early 1900s to work as stonecutters. The monument is dedicated to Carlo Abate, founder of the Barre Evening Drawing School where working people could learn the arts of vocational memorial design.

name: Italian Hall
description: The site where in 1913 at a Christmas Eve party for the children of striking miners, a person yelled fire. The false fire alarm triggered a panic. The doors only swung inward causing a press of human bodies. 73 people died, over half were children.

name: Jefferson County Jail
description: Miners who fought for recognition of the UMWA at the Battle of Blair Mountain were incarcerated here before their trial in the Jefferson County Courthouse in April, 1922. Most miners were acquitted of charges, and those convicted were paroled in 1925.
address: 325 Court St, Charles Town, WV 25414, USA

name: Jerry Rescue Monument
description: On October 1, 1851, William Henry, a black cooper, or barrel maker who went by the name of Jerry was arrested in Syracuse, New York. First he was told that he was being arrested for theft. But then he learned that federal marshals had arrested him for violating the Fugitive Slave Law, passed the year before. Jerry had escaped slavery in Missouri. The anti-slavery Liberty Party was holding its convention in nearby church. When word came about Jerry’s arrest, a crowd rushed to release him. Once released he was quickly recaptured and returned to custody. But then a large crowd, numbering more than 2,000 gathered to free Jerry from the office where he was being held. According to research done by the Syracuse University Library, the first person into the office was J. M. Clappe, an iron worker likely chosen for his brawn. The crowd was able to free Jerry and hide him until he could escape into Canada. Clappe also had to flee to Canada to avoid arrest, along with eight others. Nineteen people were indicted for participating in the rescue. Only one person was convicted, and he died before he could appeal. In turn, the abolitionists won an indictment against the marshal who had arrested Jerry. They charged him with kidnapping. Although the marshal was acquitted, it gave the abolitionists a chance to publicly challenge the constitutionality of the Fugitive Slave Act. Each year until 1858 a Jerry Rescue celebration commemorated the event. Abolitionists referred to the “Jerry Level” as a standard for justice. In 2001 a monument to the rescue was dedicated in Clinton Square, in downtown Syracuse New York. https://laborhistoryin2.podbean.com/e/october-1-the-jerry-level-1601544754?fbclid=IwY2xjawNKCUNleHRuA2FlbQIxMQBicmlkETFrQlR6cUg5dUFUUUFPRnNkAR4lUewojGHeGMAevcOaTvyNqWqcDAS5CoFYhI6MGzDgZw3x8-lYN1IZnglJYg_aem_lC73LpVd5Y4VfE4wXozhmw
address: 2 S Clinton St, Syracuse, NY 13202, USA

name: John Mitchell Memorial
description: The 1900 “Great Strike” left a legacy that continues to be important even today. In 1924, a memorial was dedicated to John Mitchell in Scranton, Pennsylvania. The marble and bronze statue was dedicated to the union leader, located at the Lackawanna County Courthouse where the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission began its hearings in November of 1902. To this day people still gather around the statue to celebrate “John Mitchell Day” on October 29, in remembrance of Mitchell’s success in the anthracite strike of 1900.
address: 200 N Washington Ave, Scranton, PA 18503, USA

name: Johnstown Corporation Plaque
description: Memorializes 3 workers at Johnstown Corporation who lost their lives on Dec 13, 1989 while at work. Hot metal escaped from a mold and the 3 men died instantly from breathing superheated air.

name: Jones, Mary Harris “Mother,” Historical Marker
description: Marks the place of Mother Jones’ death at the Burgess Farm on November 30, 1930. Jones spent the last 2 years of her life being cared for by Lillie May Burgess. Mother Jones celebrated her 100th birthday at the farm on May 1, 1930.

name: Jones, Mary Harris “Mother”, Prison Site
description: During the Paint Creek-Cabin Creek strike of 1912-1913, troopers arrested Mother Jones and illegally held her in this house for 85 days. She was still able to get messages concerning conditions of miners to a US Senate investigation committee.

name: Jones, Mary Harris “Mother” and Miners’ Monument
description: Granite spire marks the grave of Mother Jones (1830-1930), fiery champion of organized labor. Buried in 1930’s only union-owned cemetery next to “her boys”–4 miners killed in a skirmish between striking workers & mine guards at the Virden Mine in 1898.

name: Jones, Walter, Memorial
description: Jones spent his life working in the coal mines and the union. He was an officer of the union until 1917, then was brought to the district office of the UMWA and later was an international organizer until 1922 when the UMWA was forced out of Alabama.

name: Kansas City Labor History Tour
description: The tour covers the 19th to the 20th century beginning with Alderman Jim Pendergast and the West Bottoms. Includes a monument to Terence V. Powderly. Marks locations of IWW free speech fights and Ford sit-down strikes.
address: 30 W Pershing Rd, Kansas City, MO 64108, USA

name: Kate Mullany National Historic Site
description: The Kate Mullany House was declared a National Historic Landmark by the Secretary of the Interior in 1998 and designated an affiliated unit with in the National Historic Site Congress on 2005. It is located at 350 8th St. in Troy, NY. It is the home of the American Labor Studies Center.

name: Kehoe, Jack, Hibernian House
description: Nestled in Pennsylvania’s anthracite region, Jack “Blackjack” Kehoe owned this tavern; the state sentenced him to death in 1878 as a leader of the Molly Maguires.

name: Kelby, Alexander, Grave Marker
description: On June 27, 1842, Kentish guards fired on unarmed supporters of T.W. Dorr killing Alexander Kelby. Dorr led Irish laborers and reformers in holding an independent, nondiscriminatory political election, which created a separate state government.

name: Labor Hall of Fame
description: The Labor Hall of Fame honors those Americans whose distinctive contributions to the field of labor have enhanced the quality of life of millions. Included are leaders: Samuel Gompers, John L. Lewis, A. Philip Randolph, Eugene V. Debs, and Mother Jones.
address: Labor Hall of Honor, 200 Constitution Ave. NW, Washington, DC 20210, USA

name: Labor South: Center for Working Class Studies
description:
Labor South: Center for Working Class Studies brings together students, academics, workers, organizers, and artists to strengthen the movement for racial and economic justice in the US South. Labor South engages academics and movement leaders to come together through local geographic hubs, as well as a virtual center and in-person training, for political education and labor studies and to build a career pipeline with working class young people.
​

name: Lattimer Massacre Memorial & Historical Marker
description: Immigrant workers remember the site where Polish, Lithuanian and Slovak miners were gunned down by the Lattimer Sheriff deputies on Sept. 10, 1897. The miners were marching peacefully and without weapons for collective bargaining and civil liberty.
address: 62 Quality Rd, Hazle Township, PA 18202, USA

name: Letter Carriers Monument
description: Commemorates the nearby site where 60 carriers met in a room above the Schaefer’s Saloon on Aug. 30, 1889, to organize the National Association of Letter Carriers (NALC).
address: 808 N Plankinton Ave, Milwaukee, WI 53203, USA

name: Lewis, John L., Home
description: John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America (UMWA) and the Congress of Industrial Organizations (CIO), lived here from 1937-1969 and was the last resident owner of the historic home.

name: Lewis, John Llewellyn, Gravesite
description: John L. Lewis (1880-1969) was President of the United Mine Workers of America (UMWA) from 1920 to 1960. He and his union played the leading role in forming the CIO and in organizing the United Auto Workers and the United Steel Workers of America.

name: Liberty Hill Monument
description: The Marine Transport Workers Industrial Union 510 of the IWW rallied at Liberty Hill in 1923 to protest low wages, bad conditions and imprisonment of union activists. Author Upton Sinclair was arrested while attempting to read from the Bill of Rights.
address: 100 W 5th St, San Pedro, CA 90731, USA

name: Little, Frank, Gravesite
description: Marks the grave of Frank Little, who after organizing a strike of metal miners against the Anaconda Company on Aug. 1, 1917, was dragged by six masked men from his Butte hotel room and hung at the Milwaukee Railroad trestle.

name: Lopizzo, Anna, Grave Marker
description: Anna Lopizzo was killed at age 34 during the Bread and Roses Strike of 1912 in Lawrence, MA. More than 30,000 laborers were on strike for 63 days against American Woolen Co. after management cut wages.

name: Ludlow Massacre Monument
description: Pays tribute to the 19 men, women and children killed in their tent colony on April 20, 1914. The National Guard set fire to the colony and shot those who fled.

name: Lundeberg, Harry, Memorial
description: Lundeberg was a merchant seaman and an American labor leader. Joined the Seamen's Union of Australia in 1917 and transferred into the Sailors' Union of the Pacific in Seattle in 1923.
address: 450 Harrison St # 108, San Francisco, CA 94105, USA

name: Madison County Worker’s Memorial
description: The winged memorials are made from Barre granite. The statue is a life-size man carrying his hard hat and lunch pail. The memorial has a listing of workers who died on the job in Madison County.

name: Make-Up Man
description: A statue symbolizing the newspaper printing craft, the bronze was commissioned by the “New York Post.” Two compositors posed for the sculptor, Max Kalish. New York’s Typographical Union #6 secured the statue as a result of contract negotiations.

name: Marine Firemen Bas-Relief
description: Bas-relief depicts marine firemen at work in the hull of a ship.
address: 240 2nd St 2nd Fl, San Francisco, CA 94105, USA

name: Mather Mine Disaster Monument
description: 197 men died in a mine explosion in 1928. Four bodies were never found.

name: McGuire, Peter, Memorial
description: The United Brotherhood of Carpenters & Joiners of America dedicated this memorial to their founder, Peter McGuire, in 1962. McGuire was also the first secretary of the AFL.

name: McIntyre Mine Disaster Monument
description: On June 30, 1941 an explosion at the Kent No. 2 mine killed seven men. The explosion was caused by dust in the mine. This caused the area to become more aware of safety in the mines.

name: Mechanics Monument
description: The statue was erected for the workers at Union Iron Works, the first foundry built in California.

name: Memphis Strike of 1968 Monument
description: This stone recognizes the AFSCME Memphis city workers who were on strike in 1968 when Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. came to their aid.

name: Merchant Seamen Plaque
description: Merchant seamen have been responsible for merchant shipping and transportation of resources during US wars. These dangerous, yet critically important duties were most notably significant during World War II.
address: Folsom St, San Francisco, CA, USA

name: Michel Giacometti Museum of Labour
description: This museum aims to study, preserve and disseminate techniques and know-how related to the world of work, as it has changed throughout human history. Situated in the old "Perienes" canning factory, the museum features collections on local industry, trade, and regional ethnography. It is generally open Tuesday to Friday from 10 am to 6 pm and Saturday from 2 pm to 6 pm.
address: Largo Defensores da República 3 2910 470, 2910 Setúbal, Portugal

name: Michigan Labor Legacy Landmark
description: A gift to Detroit from the labor movement, “Transcending” depicts labor history, workers’ occupations and labor’s vision for the future on a grand scale. The 63-foot steel arch is surrounded by bronze reliefs detailing labor’s contributions.

name: Michigan Lumberman’s Memorial
description: Located in a small park on Michigan’s lower peninsula, overlooking the Au Sable River, this statue perpetuates the memory of the early Michigan lumber workers who were all over the Michigan countryside.
address: N St W, Tawas City, MI 48763, USA

name: Miley, J. Frank, Gravesite
description: J. Frank Miley was former president of District 31. He died in Sept. 1939. He was a forerunner of the rights of miners during the 1930s. He believed firmly in the rights to organize and bargain collectively.

name: Miner’s Union Hall
description: Built in 1876, the building named the “Miners Union Library” replaced the original Union Hall (constructed 1870).The Virginia City Miners’ Union, founded in 1867, “fought for recognition, safety, family welfare, and a living wage [of] $4.00 per day.”
address: 34 B St, Virginia City, NV 89440, USA

name: Miners’ Mound
description: Remembers Frank G. Matthews, Sr. who maintained a museum concerned with the iron miners of the area in his own home. This collection became the basis for the Michigan Iron Industry Museum.

name: Mitchell, John, Monument
description: Honors John Mitchell, UMWA President, who led Pennsylvania anthracite miners in an industry-wide strike for higher wages and better working conditions.
address: Lackawanna County Courthouse Square, Scranton, PA 18503, USA

name: Mullaney, Kate, House
description: Kate Mullaney, founder of the first female labor union in the U.S., the Collar Laundry Union, lived in this house from 1869-1875. As assistant secretary of the National Labor Union, Mullaney was the first female appointee to a national labor office.

name: Mullany, Kate, Memorial
description: In Feb. 1864, Irish immigrant Kate Mullaney organized approximately 300 women into the first female labor union in the U.S., the Collar Laundry Union. In 1868, Mullaney became the first woman to hold a leadership position in the National Labor Union.

name: Murphy, John, Memorial
description: Murphy (1882-1908), one of the first labor attorneys, successfully fought in the courts for the 8-hour day. Nicknamed “Eight Hour Murphy.” His last fight was getting William D. Haywood acquitted from trumped up charges. Murphy died March 3, 1908.
address: 430 S Quebec St, Denver, CO 80247, USA

name: Murray, Philip, Bridge
description: Spanning the creek near Curry Field, where steelworkers rallied in 1931, this bridge memorializes Philip Murray, founding member and past president of the United Steelworkers of America (USWA).
address: S 10th St Bridge, Pittsburgh, PA, USA

name: National Civil Rights Museum at Memphis
description: The National Civil Rights Museum is committed to providing educators with resources and materials for teaching the struggle for freedom and justice to students. These resources are tools for educators with tips for engaging with the museum on their visit as well as for bringing museum content into the classroom. Each educator resource will focus on an enduring idea and essential questions to broaden the scope of civil rights history.

name: National Farmer’s Memorial
description: Honors the profession of American farmers.
address: 630 N 126th St, Bonner Springs, KS 66012, USA

name: National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial
description: The Memorial honors all of America’s federal, state and local law enforcement officers who have been killed in the line of duty, dating back to the first known death in 1794.
address: 450 F St NW, Washington, DC 20001, USA

name: National Union Building
description: NOT a union building (even though the sign seems to indicate it is): The fire proof steel frame brownstone was built for the National Union Fire Insurance Company. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Union_Building
address: 918 F St NW, Washington, DC 20004, USA

name: Nevada Labor History
description: The gold and silver rush also gave birth to the oldest continually operating labor organization in Nevada, the Washoe Typographical Union, now part of Communications Workers of America Local 9413, which counts the editor of this site among its members.
address: 3300 W Sahara Ave #225, Las Vegas, NV 89102, USA

name: Nevada Law Enforcement Officers Memorial
description: Monument features plaques, inscribed poetry, and a list of Nevada law enforcement officers who lost their lives on the job.
address: 401 S Carson St, Carson City, NV 89701, USA

name: New Century Guild Building
description: The New Century Guild was founded in 1882 and was formed explicitly from the outset to address specific needs of “self-supporting women.” This was a bold step at the time when Americans believed that no self-respecting woman would work for pay.

name: New York City Labor History Map - Special Collections Center
description: The map documents the history of working people in New York City and their struggles to gain concessions such as the eight-hour work day, better pay, improved working conditions, decent and affordable housing, collective bargaining rights, healthcare, and pension plans. It also documents important aspects of the city’s political and social history, major union leaders and contributors, and their work to better conditions for workers. The map was created to be used as an alternative teaching tool.
address: Bobst Library, 70 Washington Square S floor 2, New York, NY 10012, USA

name: New York Labor History Association
description: Founded in 1976 by trade unionists, academics, students, archivists, educators, labor editors, attorneys, and retirees, mostly from New York State, NYLHA encourages the study of workers and their organizations. It serves as a bridge between the past and the present, between trade unionists and academics.
address: Bobst Library, 70 Washington Square S 2nd floor, New York, NY 10012, USA

name: Nixon, E.D., Home
description: E.D. Nixon was a porter for the Pullman Company and served as president of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters’ Union several times. As NAACP Montgomery Chapter president, Nixon recruited M.L. King Jr. to assist in the Bus Boycott of 1955-56.

name: North American Labor History Conference (NALHC)
description: For over 30 years, the North American Labor History Conference has been an annual platform for discussion and analysis about labor and working-class history from the shop floor to the international movement. Hosted by Wayne State University (Detroit, MI), NALHC encourages broad graduate student and faculty participation.
address: Walter P. Reuther Library, 5401 Cass Ave, Detroit, MI 48202, USA

name: Oklahoma Labor Heritage Foundation
description:
Oklahoma Labor Heritage Foundation honors the past, organizes the present, & fights for our future.
​

name: Old Fireman’s Hall
description: In an upstairs office on May 8,1863, the constitution of the Brotherhood of the Footboard was ratified by engineers. Later became the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.
address: 250 W Larned St, Detroit, MI 48226, USA

name: Old Labor Hall
description: Erected in 1900 by Italian immigrant stonecutters, the hall served as a place for socialist and labor meetings, and continued to be a social club until 1936. The basement served as a grocery cooperative from 1901-1926.

name: Old Row Museum
description: The boyhood home of Cardinal Edward Mooney is one of the many “company houses” built by the mining company.

name: Pacific Northwest Labor History Association
description: The Pacific Northwest Labor History Association (PNLHA) is a non-profit association dedicated to preserving the history and heritage of workers in the Pacific Northwest. We consider the “Pacific Northwest” to be British Columbia, Oregon and Washington.

name: Pennsylvania Anthracite Heritage Museum
description: The Anthracite Heritage Museum engages diverse audiences by interpreting, collecting, and presenting the story of hard coal mining, its related industries, the historic immigrant culture of northeastern Pennsylvania, and the evolution of the region’s culture.
address: 22 Bald Mountain Rd, Scranton, PA 18504, USA

name: Pennsylvania Labor History Society
description: Founded in 1973, the Pennsylvania Labor History Society (PLHS) focuses on documenting and commemorating the history of workingwomen and workingmen and their labor struggles in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. PLHS members are volunteers, including steelworkers, coal miners, postal workers, schoolteachers, social workers, factory operators, office workers, textile workers, hotel and motel workers, and students, all of whom share a love of labor history. Paul Clark is the president as of June 2025.

name: Pettibone, George, Monument
description: Pettibone was blacklisted by the mining industry, so he opened a catering shop for the Western Federation of Miners. He was labeled a “troublemaker” and was framed and jailed by Pinkerton detectives. He was acquitted in 1908.
address: 430 S Quebec St block 57 lot 88, Denver, CO 80247, USA

name: Pipeline Workers Monument
description: On June 20, 1977, oil began traveling through the trans-Alaska pipeline. 70,000 people worked on the pipeline, history’s largest privately-financed construction project.

name: Pittsburgh’s Labor History Sites ~ an Interactive Map
description:
The map points out the sites of some key moments in working class history including the 1892 Battle of Homestead, the McKees Rocks Strike, and railroad strike of 1877. The map also includes historically significant locations like the offices of the Abolitionist Newspaper, The Mystery; the homes of August Wilson, Thomas Bell, Jane Grey Swisshelm; as well as monuments to Philip Murray, Fanny Selliins, and Thomas Armstrong and Roberto Clemente.
Since both the American Federation of Labor (1881) and the Congress of Industrial Organizations (1937) were founded in Pittsburgh, the region is seen as the cradle of the American labor movement. However, the story of workers’ aspirations and struggles are not only about the unions and other organizations that represent them. From their formation, social and political forces have shaped Pittsburgh labor unions.
This map is based on the book Labor History Sites in the Pittsburgh Region published in 2015 by the Battle of Homestead Foundation and written by Charles McCollester and Howard Scott.
NOTE: as of 11/2025: "Right now our link to this map is down. We hope to reconnect soon!"

name: Pittsburgh Labor History Trail
description: Online guide created by the Battle of Homestead Foundation. "Discover the history of Pittsburgh’s labor movement with a self-guided itinerary that takes you to key sites and themes of industrial and worker struggles. Whether you’re a history buff, labor activist, or just curious about the city’s industrial past, curate your own trail and dive right in!"

name: Players Club
description: Mansion was once owned by actor Edwin Booth who left his home to the Players Club – used as group meeting place for theatrical people (club members). In 1913, library was used to form the Actors’ Equity Association.
address: 16 Gramercy Park N, New York, NY 10003, USA

name: Poultry Worker’s Memorial
description: Honors workers in a poultry factory that were killed in an explosion in 1989.

name: Powderly, Terence, Home
description: After relinquishing leadership of the Knights of Labor, Terence Powderly moved to Washington, D.C., in 1897 when he was appointed U.S. Commissioner General of Immigration. He built the home to host his many friends and Mother Jones was a frequent visitor.
address: 503 Rock Creek Church Rd NW, Washington, DC 20010, USA

name: Powderly, Terence V., Gravesite
description: Powderly, the national leader of the Knights of Labor from 1878-1893, led the organization from secrecy to national prominence. By mid-1886 the KOL numbered about one million, including women and racial minorities.
address: 201 Allison St NW, Washington, DC 20011, USA

name: Prospect V-III Mining Memorial
description: Coal was first discovered in the U.S. in nearby Georges Creek Basin during an 1872 survey conducted by George Washington. Since the birth of the U.S. coal industry, miners have experienced risk and hardship, unionization battles, and work-related disease.

name: Pullman National Historical Park
description: The Pullman Strike of 1894 shaped the American labor movement, including spurring the national adoption of Labor Day.

name: Quinn, Richard F., Monument
description: Honors Richard F. Quinn who was a letter carrier and charter member of the National Association of Letter Carriers in 1889.

name: Railroad Strike of 1877 State Historical Marker
description: Railroad and industrial workers revolted against the concentration of wealth and economic disruption resulting from technological change. In a prolonged and bloody confrontation with thousands of citizens, the Philadelphia militia killed at least 26.

name: Randolph, A. Philip, Memorial
description: Honors the labor leader and civil rights leader A. Philip Randolph, leader of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters.
address: 50 Massachusetts Ave NE, Washington, DC 20002, USA

name: Reading Marx's Capital With David Harvey
description: David Harvey’s Anti-Capitalist Chronicles is co-produced with Politics In Motion, a new nonprofit media platform. Consider supporting our work via Patreon. After five seasons hosted by Professor David Harvey and co-produced by Democracy at Work, all new episodes are now hosted and co-produced with Politics In Motion.
address: 66 W 12th St a106, New York, NY 10011, USA

name: Rincon Annex Post Office Murals
description: The WPA commissioned these indoor murals depicting the history of San Francisco, including panels of labor prisoner Tom Mooney, Harry Bridges during the 1934 General Strike, and Chinese labor building the railroads.
address: QJV4+5M, 83 Mission St, San Francisco, CA 94105, USA

name: Rochester, New York labor history site
Rochester, New York labor history sites
Rock Island Worker’s Memorial
description: Commemorates workers who have lost their lives on the job. The park where the memorial was placed is the site of the old AFL Labor Temple.

name: Rosie the Riveter Memorial
description: Marks the accomplishments and remembers the hardships of the women known as “Rosies,” who worked in the Kaiser Shipyards during WWII. 747 warships were produced at Shipyard No. 2.
address: Regatta Blvd & Marina Bay Pkwy, Richmond, CA 94804, USA

name: Sacco and Vanzetti Memorial
description: On Aug. 23, 1927, immigrant Italian anarchists Sacco and Vanzetti were accused of murder and executed after a trial widely viewed as unfair. The case became an international cause and sparked demonstrations and strikes throughout the world.

name: Sellers, Capt. Isaiah, Grave Marker
description: Captain Isaiah Sellers (c. 1802-1864) logged over one million miles at the wheel of a steamboat, and introduced the signal for passing whistle that was made into law by Congress, and is still in use by riverboats.
address: 4947 W Florissant Ave, St. Louis, MO 63115, USA

name: Sellins, Fannie and Starzeleski, Joseph, Monument
description: Marks the gravesites of Fannie Sellins and Joseph Starzeleski, who were murdered by company guards on a picket line in Brackenridge, PA, on Aug. 26, 1919. Sellins was a United Mine Workers organizer and Starzeleski was a miner.

name: Sentinel
description: Commemorates the deaths of four American Legionnaires during the Centralia Armistice Day Riot of 1919. They were killed when they attempted to enter a IWW union hall. The “official version” says they were killed for no reason during the parade.

name: Service Employees International Union Bas-Relief
description: Inscribed, “In Unity, Strength,” the relief depicts labor’s progress, from the days of early factory workers to today’s SEIU membership. (This was at SEIU, former location 1313 L street. Need to be checked, whether it moved to Mass Avenue )
address: 1800 Massachusetts Ave NW, Washington, DC 20036, USA

name: Skygate
description: Honors the longshoreman/poet/philosopher, Eric Hoffer, who died in 1983.
address: 1574 The Embarcadero, San Francisco, CA 94133, USA

name: Social and Labour History News
description:
Search collections on social history and the history of the labour movement from the late 18th to the beginning of the 21st century. More than 2.5 million records including 900,000 digitised objects (archives, books, brochures, leaflets, photographs, posters, prints, cartoons, sound, films and videos) from 23 specialized archives and libraries.
​

name: Southern Illinois Coal Miners Memorial
description: Dedicated to the coal miners of southern Illinois. Celebrates the 100th Anniversary of the United Mine Workers of America.
address: 720 S Main St, Marissa, IL 62257, USA

name: Southern Labor Studies Association (SLSA)
description: SLSA’s mission is to organize the Southern Labor Studies Conference as well as sessions on southern working class history at other venues. We are also dedicated to enhancing connections between academics and labor activists in the U.S. South, and promoting working class history in public school curricula by provide resources for public school teachers.
address: The Athletic Center, 2000 Lakeshore Dr, New Orleans, LA 70148, USA

name: St. John, Vincent, Memorial
description: Honors Vincent St. John, a great labor organizer who died poor and was buried in an unmarked grave. “The Saint” was a founder of both the Western Federation of Miners and the Industrial Workers of the World (IWW).

name: Strasser, Adolph, Gravesite
description: Marks the grave of Adolph Strasser who was the head of the Cigar Makers Union and one of the founders of the AFL in 1886. Strasser died on Jan. 1, 1939.
address: 863 Des Plaines Ave, Forest Park, IL 60130, USA

name: Sturdivant, John, Bust
description: John Sturdivant was the president of the American Federation of Government Employees (AFGE) from 1988 until his death in 1997. He is credited with revitalizing AFGE as a key players in federal personnel issues.
address: Labor Hall of Honor, 200 Constitution Ave. NW, Washington, DC 20210, USA

name: Sylvis, William, Monument
description: Marks the grave of William Sylvis who was a founder of the Molders Union, and became president in 1863. Also founded the International Journal, was devoted to the idea of International Unions. He advocated women and African-American memberships in unions.
address: 6501 E Baltimore Ave, Lansdowne, PA 19050, USA

name: Sylvis, William H., Historical Marker
description: Labor history advocates placed a marker to William Sylvis on the present campus of Indiana University of Pennsylvania. It notes his birthplace in Indiana County, Pa. Sylvis founded the Molders’ Union in 1859 and the National Labor Union in 1868.
address: Locust St & Pratt Dr, Indiana, PA 15705, USA

name: Talbot, Tom, Statue
description: Tom Talbot was the founder and first president of the International Association of Machinists.

name: Teamwork
description: On July 14, 1999, Iron Workers Local 8 members, Jeffrey Wischer, William DeGrave and Jerome Starr were killed in a crane accident while working on Miller Park Stadium. Approximately 6,000 people spent more than 200 million hours building Miller Park.

name: Tejo Power Station, AKA Museum of Electricity
description: This museum is housed in a group of buildings classified as national heritage - the Central Tejo or Lisbon power station. Besides the building itself, the main interest is the machinery used to supply electricity to the city of Lisbon in the first half of the 20C. It includes 19C dynamos and electric motors, steam engines, high-pressure boilers, hydraulic generators and other tools and equipment. Includes great representations of the work and workers involved in the power station's work.

name: The Global Labour History Network
description: LAWCHA an interdisciplinary network of historians and other social scientists, founded in Barcelona on June 16, 2015. It unites local, national and regional scholarly associations, journals, archives and museums, as well as committed individuals, who aspire to further the study of work and workers in the broadest sense.
address: Carr Bldg, 1356 Campus Dr, Durham, NC 27705, USA

name: The International Association of Labour History Institutions (IALHI)
description:
The International Association of Labour History Institutions (IALHI) brings together archives, libraries, documentation centres, museums and research institutions specializing in the history and theory of the labour and social movements from all over the world. IALHI's main goal is to facilitate the exchange of expertise in order to preserve, and promote the access to, and the use of, their respective collections.
Amsterdam, Netherlands

name: The Irish American Museum
description: The Irish American Museum focuses on the Irish immigrants who arrived in the years of the Great Hunger, also known as the Potato Famine and walks you through the home and life of James and Sarah Feeley. You’ll learn about the crisis they faced in Ireland, treacherous journey across the Atlantic and development of a new way of life in a vibrant, thriving city.

name: The People’s History Museum
description: The People’s History Museum is the national museum of democracy, telling the story of its development in Britain: past, present, and future. Explore the radical stories of people coming together to champion ideas worth fighting for, and be empowered by the past to make a change for the future.

name: The Youngstown Historical Center of Industry & Labor
description: Known locally as the "Steel Museum," YHCIL documents the rise and fall of the steel industry in Youngstown and the Mahoning Valley. Our exhibits combine artifacts, videotaped interviews and full-scale recreations of the places where steelworkers lived and worked, in a tribute to the men and women who forged a way of life from iron and steel for almost two centuries.
address: 151 W Wood St, Youngstown, OH 44503, USA

name: Thompson, J.C., Home & Historical Marker
description: In April 1863, a meeting here formed the Brotherhood of the Footboard (renamed Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers in 1864). J.C. Thompson was one of the founders.
address: 633 W Hanover St, Marshall, MI 49068, USA

name: TOTH Mining Memorial
description: The 1874 confirmation of gold in the Black Hills marked the beginning of the Gold Rush. Ignoring an 1868 treaty, prospectors flocked to the area. Mining came to represent both wealth for whites, and cultural destruction for Native Americans. .
address: 501 E St Joseph St, Rapid City, SD 57701, USA

name: Train Whistle Monument
description: Commemorates thousands of railroad shop workers who contributed to building communities in central Illinois. The railroad shops first opened in Bloomington in 1854 and produced railroad cars.
address: 907 W Wood St, Bloomington, IL 61701, USA

name: Transport Workers Union of America (TWU)
description: Is a United States labor union that was founded in 1934 by subway workers in New York City, then expanded to represent transit employees in other cities, primarily in the eastern U.S. This article discusses the parent union and its largest local, Local 100, which represents the transport workers of New York City. TWU is a member of the AFL–CIO.

name: Triangle Fire Ladder Plaque
description: Dedicated to the firemen of Company 20 that responded to the Fire at Triangle Shirtwaist Company on March 25, 1911. 146 workers were killed in the fire.

name: Triangle Fire Plaque (cemetery)
description: Commemorates the 146 workers (mostly female) that died when their factory caught on fire. Most died because the fire doors were locked. There was no fire alarm system, no sprinklers, an inoperative fire hose & the only fire escape didn’t reach the ground.

name: Triangle Fire Plaque (factory site)
description: Garment workers mark the site, near Washington Square, of the Triangle Shirtwaist Fire of March 25, 1911 where 146 mostly female workers lost their lives. The fire spurred safety movements by unions.

name: Tribute to Nevada Miners Statue
description: In recognition of, and in tribute to the miners who worked in the Nevada mine industry from the mid-1800s on.
address: 401 S Carson St, Carson City, NV 89701, USA

name: UAW West Side Local 174 WPA Mural
description: Depicting the history of labor and the United Auto Workers (UAW), the mural shows the “Battle of the Overpass” and the sit-down strike. The artist, Walter Speck, was the head of the Works Progress Administration (WPA) in Detroit.
address: 29841 Van Born Rd, Romulus, MI 48174, USA

name: United Mine Workers of America International Headquarters, 1937-99
description: Under the leadership of John L. Lewis, the United Mine Workers of America (UMWA) moved their headquarters to Washington, D.C., in 1937. The union sold the building in 1999.

name: VDOT Workers' Memorial
description: Highway lookout that features a memorial honoring state workers killed on the job.

name: Victor Miners Hall History
description:
We are a group of individuals who share an intense passion for the history of this area, and an understanding of the vital importance of preserving this national treasure. Colorado labor history records struggles by coal miners and by hard rock miners relating to issues such as wages, work hours, and working conditions.
richardmyers (at) q.com

name: Waite, Governor Davis H., Monument
description: During the Cripple Creek strike of 1893-94, Gov. Waite took the unprecedented action of calling out state militia to protect striking workers. The Governor also helped to negotiate a peaceful settlement to the strike.

name: Walter and May Reuther UAW Black Lake Conference Center
description: In 1946, Walter Reuther was elected president of the United Auto Workers and in 1952, the head of the CIO. In 1955, he became vice president of the merged AFL-CIO. Reuther supported both civil rights and social welfare legislation during his labor career.

name: Washington DC Labor History items (see CG's list)
Washington National Cathedral’s Labor Windows
