description: The three stained glass windows honor the contributions of America’s labor unions by featuring individual union seals. Each window is dedicated to the work of the labor leaders Samuel Gompers, Philip Murray, and William Green.
address: 3101 Wisconsin Ave NW, Washington, DC 20016, USA

name: West Virginia Workers’ Memorial
description: Monument erected in the honor of workers everywhere who have lost their lives to the workplace.
address: 501 Leon Sullivan Way, Charleston, WV 25301, USA

name: WFM Local #32 Miners’ Union Hall,
description: To secure the 8-hour-day and unionize the gold fields, the Western Federation of Miners (WFM) led a strike in the Cripple Creek area from 1903-04. Gov. James H. Peabody worked with corporate mining interests, using the state militia to crush the union.

name: White, John P., Gravesite
description: John P. White was the 7th international president of the United Mine Workers of America (UMWA) from 1911-1917. Renowned for his achievement of winning the 8-hour day in the anthracite region, he was a key figure in lifting wages and working standards.
address: 4909 University Ave, Des Moines, IA 50311, USA

name: Wilberg Coal Mine Disaster Memorial
description: Honors the victims (both men and women) of the Wilberg Coal Mine Disaster of Dec.19, 1984 – called the worst coal mine fire disaster in Utah history. 26 men and one woman were killed.

name: Wisconsin Labor History Society
description: Formed in 1981, the Wisconsin Labor History Society exists to continue the heritage developed by the state’s workers and union activists. We are dedicated to: telling the public of the contributions of labor to Wisconsin; getting labor’s story in the schools and colleges; and preserving documents and records of workers and their unions.
address: 6333 W Bluemound Rd, Milwaukee, WI 53213, USA

name: Workday Minnesota essays on Minnesota labor history
description: On March 31, workers, students, and allies rallied together on the steps of Johnston Hall, which contains the office of the University of Minnesota President Rebecca Cunningham’s, to protest what they criticize as the University’s failure to forcefully object to ICE’s recent abduction of a graduate student, and an onslaught of University policies limiting the freedom of speech across campus.

name: Workers Memorial Tower
description: The memorial tower was a part of the bridge that carried workers across tracks and yards of the Reading Railroad. It was known as the “Swinging Bridge.”

name: Working: Voices from the 20th century
description: The ”Bridgeport Working: Voices from the Twentieth Century” was the concept of former BHC Department Head, Mary K. Witkowski. As Director of the History Center, Witkowski understood the important role that labor has played in Bridgeport’s history. The Twentieth Century saw two world wars, a depression, the expansion of civil service, and radical changes in the American manufacturing landscape along with the mass migration within and immigration to the United States.

name: Working-Class Studies Association
description:
The Working-Class Studies Association was formed in 2005 to support and promote interdisciplinary and activist projects focused on working-class lives and culture. The WCSA publishes a semi-annual newsletter, holds annual conferences, sponsors an awards competition, and provides online resources.
​

name: Working in Paterson: Occupational Heritage in an Urban Setting
description: This collection presents 470 interview excerpts and 3882 photographs from the Working in Paterson Folklife Project of the American Folklife Center at the Library of Congress. The four-month study of occupational culture in Paterson, New Jersey, was conducted in 1994. The documentary materials presented in this online collection explore how Paterson's industrial heritage expresses itself in Paterson: in its work sites, work processes, and memories of workers. Included are interpretive essays exploring such topics as work in the African American community, local foodways, the ethnography of a single work place (Watson Machine International), business life along a single street in Paterson (21st Avenue), and narratives told by retired workers.
address: 101 Independence Ave SE, Washington, DC 20540, USA
